events.event_description: Coal stockpiles at U.S. electric power plants reached 138 million short tons, the highest level since the first half of 2020.
events.citation: Coal stockpiles at U.S. electric power plants totaled 138 million short tons at the end of May, the most since the first half of 2020 when the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic reduced electricity demand and coal consumption.

events.event_description: Coal consumption by the U.S. electric power sector totaled 385 million tons in 2023, representing a 43% decline from 2016 levels.
events.citation: Coal consumption by the electric power sector totaled 385 million tons in 2023, 43% less than in 2016.

events.event_description: Coal stockpiles at U.S. power plants reached 131 million tons by the end of 2023, showing a 19% decrease compared to 2016 levels.
events.citation: Coal stockpiles reached 131 million tons by the end of 2023, 19% less than stockpiles at the end of 2016.

events.event_description: Over 90% of U.S. coal-fired power plants currently maintain sufficient coal stockpiles to generate electricity for 60 days or more.
events.citation: U.S. coal power plants generally stockpile much more coal than they consume in a month, with more than 90% of coal-fired power plants currently having enough coal on hand to generate electricity for 60 days or more.
